metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Effect of essential oils on the immune response to some viral vaccines in broiler chickens, with special reference to Newcastle disease virus Effect of essential oils on the immune response to some viral vaccines in broiler 3 chickens, with special reference to Newcastle disease virus 4

abstract.text: Please cite this article as: El-Shall N.A., Shewita R.S., Abd El-Hack M.E., AlKahtane A., Alarifi S., Alkahtani S., Abdel-Daim M.M. & Sedeik M.E., Effect of essential oils on the immune response to some viral vaccines in broiler chickens, with special reference to Newcastle disease virus, Poultry Science (2020), doi: https://doi.(Mohamed E. Abd El-Hack). 21 (1952±28.82) did not significantly (p>0.05) improve growth performance compared to 41 the non-treated birds (NC and VC) (1970±19.56 and 1904±38.66). Essential oils 42 showed an antiviral effect on vNDv in vivo (in chickens) as a preventive measure 43 (PRV) as well as some therapeutic effect (TTT) through decreasing the viral shedding 44 titres (loNC 0 ), mortality rate, and severity of clinical signs and post mortem lesions, in 45 addition to serum malondialdhyde (MDA) level. Regarding the other viruses, the EOs 46

mixture did not improve the immune response to the AI and IB vaccines but age (2108±341.05). The studied EOs mixture showed an immune stimulating response 49 to ND and IBD vaccines, antiviral effect against ND virus especially if administered 50 before the challenge, however it did not have a growth promoting effect. 51 52

body_text.text: All birds in the experimental groups except NC (negative control) were challenged 126 with vNDv genotype VII at 28 th d. Vaccinated groups (VC, VTC, PRV and TTT) 127 received the vaccination program shown in (Table 1) (1991) as follows: total red and white blood cell counts were determined manually 158 using a haemocytometer. The packed cell volume was measured by a capillary tube 159 technique using micro-haematocrit capillary tubes centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 5 min. 160
The haemoglobin concentration was measured by the cyanomethemoglobin method. 161
The differential leukocyte count was carried out using blood smears stained with 162
Wrights-Giemsa stain according to their identification characteristics, and the 163 percentage and absolute value for each cell type were calculated. 164

Phagocytic assay was determined according to Kawahara et al. Duncan's test. The data are presented as the average ±SE. All statements of differences 218 were based on a significance level of P<0.05. Coefficient of variation percentage 219 (CV%) of all groups were calculated according to the following equation: (y/x)*100 as 220 y is standard deviation of the treatment and x is mean value of the same treatment. 221

body_text.section: Immune response to NDv and results of subsequent vNDv challenge 223

body_text.text: The average level of maternally derived antibodies specific for NDv (HI) was 2 log 225 5.63 ± 0.18, that decreased over time in the non-vaccinated control groups (NC and PC) 226
body_text.section: Immune response to NDv and results of subsequent vNDv challenge 223

body_text.text: to reach values of (2 log 3.13 ± 0.40 and 3.38 ± 0.46, respectively) at 28 th d (challenge 227 day). In addition, Newcastle disease-vaccinated birds (VC) did not show significantly 228 higher HI titres (p≥0.05) (2 log 4 ± 0.87) at the challenge day than NC or PC birds 229 (non-vaccinated). However, the use of EOs in combination with vaccine application 230 against ND in VTC increased HI antibody titre (2 log 4.5 ± 0.27) (p≥ 0.05) than VC 231 (vaccinated only). 232
body_text.section: Immune response to NDv and results of subsequent vNDv challenge 223

body_text.text: Positive control birds (PC) showed a significant increase (p< 0.05) of HI titre (2 233 log 10.57 ± 0.43) for NDv at 35 th d (7 days PC). While, sero-conversion post vNDv 234 challenge was significantly (p< 0.05) lower as a result of using EOs together with ND vaccines in VTC (2 log 6.5 ± 0.46) than the vaccine alone in VC (2 log 8.63 ± 0.65).
body_text.section: Immune response to NDv and results of subsequent vNDv challenge 223

body_text.text: starting from 1 day before vNDv challenge (PRV) or 2 days after challenge (TTT) and 238 continued for 5 days, but the difference was not significant (p≥ 0.05) comparing to VC 239 or VTC (Fig. 1) . 240
body_text.section: Immune response to NDv and results of subsequent vNDv challenge 223

body_text.text: The vNDv challenge in the experimental groups resulted in the death of 17/21 birds 242 (80.95%) in PC (non-vaccinated and non-treated), which was reduced by vaccination 243 against ND in VC to 52.28% (11/21). Moreover, the use of EOs with vaccination as an 244 immune modulator in VTC reduced the mortality rate to 42.86% (9/21), whereas 245 preventive and therapeutic groups (PRV and TTT) showed mortality rate of 38.09% 246 (8/21) and 47.62% (10/21), respectively ( Table 2) Table  251 2). 252

Upon examination of dead birds, congestion of the pectoral muscles and trachea, 253 proventricular haemorrhage, button-like ulcers on the small intestine, and a mottled 254 enlarged spleen were observed (Fig. 2, Table 2 ). 255 and 7 th day PC and were pooled. No oropharyngeal viral shedding was observed in the 259 negative control birds (NC) throughout the experimental period. The peak of viral 260 shedding (loNC 0 ) was recorded at the 4 th day PC in all challenged experimental groups 261 and the highest titre was produced by the positive control group (PC) at all 3 intervals, 262

whereas the lowest titre (loNC 0 ) was recorded in birds from PRV, followed by VTC 263 and finally TTT as viral shedding titre (loNC 0 ) was 6.59, 4.76, 3.73, 3.11, and 4.1 at 2 nd 264 day PC, 6.99, 4.98, 3.94, 2.78, and 4.52 at 4 th day PC and 5.44, 3.29, 2.28, 1.88, and 3.5 265 at 7 th day PC in PC, VC, VTC, PRV and TTT, respectively (Fig. 3) . 266
There was no significant difference (p≥0.05) in average body weight gain (g) among 268 the experimental groups during the period from one day until the day of challenge 269
(1 st -28 th d). However, the average body weight gain during 7 days post challenge was 270 significantly reduced (p<0.05) in non-vaccinated challenged birds (PC) ( Table 3 . 291

The level of SOD did not significantly differ (p≥0.05) at 28 th d (challenge day) as 237.5, 293 237.5, 287.5, 262.5, 287.5, and 287.5 U/mL and 35 th d (7 days PC) as 337.5, 325, 350, 294 350, 337.5, and 350 U/mL in NC, PC, VC, VTC, PRV, and TTT respectively. MDA 295 level did not statistically affected (p>0.05) at the challenge day (28 th d) as 9.92, 9.92, 296 9.28, 9.73, 9.28 , and 9.28 nmol/mL, but it was significantly impacted (P <0.05) at seven days post challenge (35 th d) as 9. 93, 9.94, 9.56, 9.59, 9.15 Phagocytic activity (PA) and the phagocytic index were significantly higher in NC 327 (negative control) (48 and 28, respectively) than in VC (vaccinated and non-treated 328 with EOs) (32.67 and 10, respectively) and VTC (vaccinated and treated with EOs) 329 (37.5 and 13.5, respectively), with a significant increase (p<0.05) in VTC in 330 comparison to VC (Table 4) . 331
Spleen, thymus and liver indices weren't statistically different (p≥0.05) between 332

EOs treated group (VTC) and other non-treated ones (NC and VC) at 28 th d with a range 333 of difference of 0.7:0.95, 3.51:4.48, and 23.81:27.14, respectively. However, the bursa 334 of Fabricius index was significantly (p<0.05) higher in VTC (1.08) than in NC group 335 (0.54) ( Table 4) . 336

FIGREF0.text: virulent ND virus genotype VII (vNDv genotype VII) by using the 26 following experimental groups of broiler chickens (each group had 21 birds with three 27 replicates in each, n=seven): NC (negative control), PC (positive control), VC 28 (vaccinated), and VTC (vaccinated and treated with EOs). Moreover, in a trial to study 29 the effect of EOs on vNDv genotype VII in vivo as a preventive or therapeutic measure, 30 two additional ND-vaccinated groups were used (PRV: medicated one day before 31 vNDv challenge for 5 days; and TTT: medicated two days post vNDv challenge for 5 32 days). In addition, the immune-modulatory effect of EOs on the avian influenza (AI), 33 infectious bronchitis (IB) and infectious bursal disease (IBD) vaccines was assessed 34 through the serological response. The use of EOs along with administration of ND 35 vaccines (VTC) revealed lower mortality rate (42.86%), clinical signs and post mortem 36 lesion score (11) comparing to ND vaccines alone (VC) (52.28% mortality and score 37 15), in addition to lower hemagglutination inhibition (HI) (p<0.05) (6.5±0.46) and viral 38 shedding (10 log 2.28±0.24) titres one week post challenge in comparison with of VC 39 (8.63±0.65 and 10 log 3.29±0.72, respectively). Nevertheless, the EOs mixture (VTC) 40 significantly (p<0.05) increased the ELISA antibody titre for IBD virus at 28 th day of INTRODUCTION 55 Avian viral diseases caused by AI, IB, IBD, and ND viruses are a major obstacle in the 56 poultry industry worldwide and result in substantial economic losses, especially in 57 broilers, due to respiratory distress, high mortality, impaired growth or immune 58 suppression. Furthermore, they have the capability of inducing diseases independently 59 or in concurrent infection with each other (Roussan et al., 2008). Avian influenza 60 viruses are classified in the genus Influenza virus of Orthomyxoviridae family (Cox et 61 al., 2000), while the etiology of IBD or Gumboro disease is the infectious bursal disease 62 virus that is a member of genus Avibirnavirus of Birnaviridae family (Delmas et al., 63 2019). Infectious bronchitis virus is belonging to Coronavirus genus of family 64 hatchery and divided, by the ranking method to uniform initial body weight, into six 115 groups (n = 21 with three replicates in each, n = seven), as follows: 116 NC: non-vaccinated, non-treated and non-challenged (Negative control) 117 PC: non-vaccinated, non-treated and vNDv challenged (Positive control) 118 VC: vaccinated, non-treated and vNDv challenged (Vaccinated, challenged) 119 VTC: vaccinated, treated (EOs treatment was started after each vaccine and continued 120 for 3 days), and vNDv challenged (Vaccinated, treated and challenged) 121 PRV: vaccinated and treated (EOs treatment was started one day before vNDv 122 challenge and continued for 5 days) (Preventive group) 123 TTT: vaccinated and treated (EOs treatment was started two days after vNDv challenge 124 and continued for 5 days) (Therapeutic group) 125

FIGREF1.text: Candida albicans culture was added to 1 mL of citrated blood collected 167 from 6 birds (individually) in each group (NC, VC, and VTC) (2/replicate) and shaken 168 in a water bath at 25ºC for 5 h. Blood smears were then stained with Wrights-Giemsa 169 stain. Phagocytosis was estimated by determining the proportion of macrophages that 170 contained intracellular yeast cells in a random count of 300 macrophages and was 171 expressed as the percentage of phagocytic activity (PA). for NC, VC, and VTC (2 birds/ replicate) at 28 th d and were weighed individually to 176 calculate the relative organ weights and represented as organ index. 177 Organ index = {organ weight (gram)/body weight (gram)} × 1000 (Hedayati et al., 178 2005). 179 Clinical and post mortem investigations, mortality rate and growth performance 180 The mortality rate was recorded, and all birds in the experimental groups were daily 181 observed for seven days post challenge (PC). For clinical signs, including sneezing, 182 rales, swollen head, nasal and ocular discharge, greenish diarrhoea, torticollis, and 183 recumbency, as well as dead birds were examined for post mortem lesions, such as 184 proventricular haemorrhage, intestinal button-like ulcers, ileocaecal tonsil 185 haemorrhage, and congested pectoral muscles and tracheal mucosa (OIE, 2012). The 186 birds were individually weighed to determine the body weight at 1 st , 28 th and 35 th day, 187 and weight gain was calculated for each bird at 1-28, 28-35 and 1-35 day intervals. The 188 average feed consumption per bird was determined at the same intervals. 189 The feed conversion ratio (FCR) was calculated as FCR per bird = {total feed 190 consumption in a pen ÷ (weight gain of surviving birds + weight gain of dead birds in 191 the same pen)} (Conway and McKenzie, 2007). 192 shedding titres on oropharyngeal swabs 196 Oropharyngeal swabs were taken from all surviving birds in each group at 2 nd , 4 th and 197 7 th day PC in 1.5 mL of PBS containing gentamicin (200 μg/mL) and penicillin G (1000 198 units/mL). The collected swabs were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min; the 199 supernatants were collected and stored at -80°C until use. RNA was extracted from 200 200 μL of the collected oropharyngeal swab fluid using Thermo Scientific Gene JET Viral 201 DNA and RNA Extraction Kits (USA) following the manufacturer's recommended 202 procedures. The ND virus fusion protein gene was amplified using the primers and 203 probe according to AlHabeeb et al. (2013) with the Stratagene Real-Time PCR system. 204 The reaction was composed of 5 μL of template RNA, 12.5 μL of rRT-PCR Master 205 Mix, 1.25 μL of RT-enhancer, 0.25 μL of enzyme mix, 1 μL of forward primer (50 206 pmol), 1 μL of reverse primer (50 pmol), 0.25 μL of probe, and 3.75 μL of RNAse free 207water. The PCR cycling conditions were 50 cycles at 94°C for 10 s, 58°C for 5 s, and 208 72°C for 10 s preceded by an initial denaturation for 15 min at 95°C. 209Measurement of antioxidant enzymes 210Malondialdehyde (MDA) and superoxide dismutase (SOD) in serum were estimated 211 according toSatoh (1978) andNishikimi et al. (1972), respectively, using commercial 212 kits produced by Biodiagnostic Co. (diagnostic and research reagents) at 28 th and 35 th d.(SAS, 2004) by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by post hoc 217

FIGREF2.text: . All birds in the negative control 247 group (NC) appeared clinically normal, while vNDv challenge resulted in depression, 248 swollen head, conjunctivitis, rales, sneezing and nasal discharge beginning at the 2 nd 249 day post challenge (PC) in all experimentally challenged groups (PC, VC, VTC, PRV 250and TTT). Greenish diarrhoea was also recorded in PC, VTC, and TTT(Fig. 2,

FIGREF3.text: age of challenge (28 th d). Consistent with the reports of Sadeghi et al. (2012) 341 and Rahimi et al. (2011). In contrast, Barbour et al. (2014) and Thaje and Ulaiwi (2017) 342 showed that the addition of eucalyptus and mint oils improved the humoral immune 343 responses to ND virus in broilers. In addition, Wati et al. (2015) reported an 344 improvement in the humoral response (HI titre) to ND virus at 21 th d in broilers after 345 using a phytogenic product, but this effect did not last to 39 th d. 346 Though the obtained result for VTC [vaccinated, EOs treated (after each vaccine) 347 and challenged], an improvement of clinical protection (mortality, clinical signs, PM 348 lesions and viral shedding titre) was observed. This could be due to stimulating effect 349 on cell-mediated and local immunity (Cserep, 2008) and therefore eliminating some of 350 the viruses from tissues (Awaad et al., 2009). The penetration mechanism of the virus 351 into the cells determines whether the virus is affected by the EOs or not and where ND 352 virus penetrates cells through a fusion protein (Cermelli et al., 2008), which in turn can 353 be resistant to Eos (Barbour et al., 2010), so not all ND viruses are affected by Eos. 354 While, AI virus penetrates the cells through a receptor-mediated endocytosis 355 mechanism (Swayne and King, 2003). 356As many studies have discussed the In vitro antiviral activity of EOs against 357 avian viruses after contact between viruses and EOs for certain periods of time at room 358 temperature(Barbour et al., 2010), here we designed PRV and TTT to study the either before (PRV) or after vNDv challenge (TTT). The improvement of the clinical and pathological picture of vNDv was observed in PRV (received the EOs supplement 362 that was started from 1 day before the challenge and was continued for 5 days); in 363 addition, this group had the lowest oropharyngeal shedding titre (log 10 ), which could 364 be due to eucalyptus, as well it has been used in traditional medicine to treat respiratory 365tract infections (Cermelli et al., 2008) and may exhibit antiviral activity (Barbour et al., 366 2010) and thus affects the virulence of the challenge virus. Moreover, EOs showed 367 more protective level against vNDv challenge in PRV (preventive group) than TTT 368 (therapeutic group) that may be attributed to the effect of EOs mixture on ND virus 369 adsorption to cell surface and may block cell receptors resulting in interference with 370 virus binding; and its accurate mode of action should be studied through tissue culture. 371 Essential oils supplementation, during the period of 1 st to 28 th d, in VTC did not 372 significantly improve body weight gain compared to the other non-treated groups (NC 373 and VC). Although, VTC showed an improved FCR (1.77±0.03), it did not 374 significantly differ from negative control birds (NC) (1.66±0.04). Vaccination by 375 different live vaccines including ND, IB, and IBD viruses may be the reason for 376 significantly higher FCR in VC (1.89±0.04). The same was observed during 7 days PC 377 for body weight gain and FCR. Nevertheless, the use of ND vaccines, regardless EOs 378 supplementation has improved (p>0.05) overall body weight gain in all challenged 379 groups compared to the positive control group. Similar results were obtained by Sedeik 380 et al. (2019). Supplementation of EOs as a preventive drug in PRV (that was started from 1 day before the challenge and continued for 5 days) along with vaccines 382 application has significantly improved the body weight gain compared to positive 383 control birds (PC). 384 The worst FCR was recorded in PC, followed by VC and TTT. In contrast, 385 El-Ghousein and Al-Beitawi (2009), Awaad et al. (2016), and Thaje and Ulaiwi (2017) 386 reported that essential oils of eucalyptus, mint and/or thyme oils resulted in significant 387 increase in the body weight and weight gain, in addition to improving the FCR.The EOs 388 enhance digestibility, balance the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) microflora and stimulate 389 the secretion of endogenous digestive enzymes, thus improve growth performance in 390 poultry (Williams and Losa, 2001; Cross et al., 2007). As well, thymol plus carvacrol 391 has reported to significantly improve body weight gain and FCR in broilers 392 (Hashemipour et al., 2013; Saki et al., 2014). The obtained results of body weight gain 393 and FCR in this study were similar to the findings of Rehman et al. (2013), Toghyani et 394 al. (2010) and Lee et al. (2003). The various results of the effect of different types of 395 EOs on bird performance in several studies could be related to variations of dose, active 396 components of the EOs mixture, the period of administration, and the environmental 397 and nutritional factors. 398 Lipid peroxidation is an autocatalytic process that leads to oxidative damage of 399 cellular membranes (Rhee et al., 1996) and cell death, producing toxic free radicals 400 including MDA which is used as an indicator of lipid peroxidation (Jensen et al., 1997), 401 while the antioxidative enzyme, SOD, protects cells from the damage caused by these of MDA in PRV and TTT at 35 th day although vNDv challenge didn't increase MDA 405 level in PC (positive control). These results make us ask about the role of ND infection 406 on lipid peroxidation and therefore the need for further studies. The decreased level of 407 MDA at 7 th d PC in VTC may be attributed to the antioxidant effect of thyme that is rich 408 in flavonoids (Cook and Samman, 1996). Furthermore, Youdim and Deans (2000), 409 Botsoglou et al. (2002) and Hashemipour et al. (2013) reported that thymol, carvacrol, 410 thyme oil, and/or oregano have strong antioxidant activity and can inhibit lipid 411 peroxidation. 412 Regarding the immune-stimulating effect of the EOs mixture for other vaccines, 413 AI and IB antibody titres were not affected by EOs supplementation, but that of IBD 414 virus significantly increased only at 28 th d. Similar results were obtained by Saki et al. 415 (2014) for AI and IB, but are not consistent for IBD, which could be due to the use of 416 thyme essence in the drinking water at different doses (0, 0.10, 0.15 and 0.20 mL/L) 417 from 8 to 42 days or the inclusion of different components. The haematological and 418 phagocytic activity assays were conducted only at 28 th day of age to detect the effect of 419 EOs on the immune response to vaccines (regardless of ND challenge). So the groups 420 were representing by NC: negative control, VC: vaccinated and non-treated with EOs, 421 and VTC: vaccinated and treated with EOs. One of the first lines of defence in the body 422 is leucocytes, which significantly increase in its number when the infection occurs (Ganong, 1999), like what was observed in this study in VC (vaccinated, non-treated). In addition to the lower H: L ratio in VTC (vaccinated and EOs treated), which may be 425 due to the positive influence of this mixture on reducing stress in broilers. It is known 426 that the H: L ratio is considered as an indicator of stress in poultry (Bedanova et al., 427 2007). Similar results were reported by Hashemipour et al. (2013). Additionally, 428 essential oils were able to increase the phagocytic activity (PA) and index in VTC 429 compared to VC. On the other hand, eucalyptus oil stimulates the immune response by 430 enhancing PA of monocytes (El-Ghousein and Al-Beitawi, 2009). Furthermore, 431 Acamovic and Brooker (2005) claimed that the polyphenol compound EO and thymol 432 have a stimulating effect on mononuclear phagocyte system and cellular immunity. 433 As reported in Table 4, lymphoid organ and liver index, red blood cell counts, 434 haemoglobin percentage, and haematocrit value were not affected by EOs 435 supplementation. Similar findings were reported by Hashemipour et al. (2013). 436 However, Al-Kassie (2009) showed that the supplementation of the oil extract of thyme 437 and cinnamon resulted in increasing red blood cell count, haematocrit, and 438 haemoglobin values compared to those of the control birds. 439 CONCLUSIONS 440 In conclusion, the EOs mixture used in the present study has a positive preventive effect 441 and some therapeutic effect on ND virus infection in chickens (in vivo) through the 442 decreased viral shedding titre, increased clinical protection, and decreased pathological 443 picture. EOs did not promote the bird's performance or the immune responses to the AI and IB vaccines; nevertheless it has an immune stimulating effect for the IBD virus. Further studies are required for determining their antiviral mode of action to help 446 control different field outbreaks and to decrease viral shedding in addition extended their appreciation to the Deanship of Scientific Research at King 450 Saud University for funding this work through College of Food and Agriculture 451 Sciences Research Center.. FIGREF5.text: 8%. B.wt gain (g): body weight gain (gram). FCR (g/g): feed conversion ratio (gram of feed intake/gram of weight gain). NC: Negative control, PC: Positive control, VC: Vaccinated and challenged, VTC: Vaccinated, treated and challenged, PRV: Haemagglutination inhibition (HI) titre (log 2) of Newcastle disease antibodies throughout the experimental period 1 . 1 Geometric mean of twelve serum samples per group (four/replicate) at each observation time. Different letters at each observation time indicate to significant difference (p<0.05). NC: negative control, PC: positive control, VC: vaccinated and challenged, VTC: vaccinated, treated and challenged, PRV: preventive and TTT: therapeutic group.

FIGREF6.text: Clinical signs and post mortem lesions in experimental groups challenged with vNDv. A: depression, B: swollen head and closed eye lids, C: greenish diarrhoea, D: proventricular haemorrhage, E: congested trachea, F: button-like ulcers on the intestine, G: enlarged mottled spleen. Viral shedding (loNC 0 ) in the oropharyngeal swabs at 2, 4, and 7 days post challenge in six experimental chicken groups 1 . 1 Data are the average of three replicates per group (two pooled samples/replicate). NC: negative control, PC: positive control, VC: vaccinated and challenged, VTC: vaccinated, treated and challenged, PRV: preventive and TTT: therapeutic group.

TABREF0.text: against ND, IB, IBD and AI. The 128 feeding program consisted of starter feed (crumbles) for the first 12 days with 23% 129 crude protein and metabolizable energy (ME) of 3008 Kcal/kg diet, grower feed 130 (pellets) (21% crude protein and 3080 Kcal/kg diet ME) up to 26 th day, followed by 131 finisher (pellets) feed till end of the experiment (35 days) with 19% crude protein and 132 chicks were received at 32°C on day 1 and then the temperature was decreased linearly 134 by 2°C per week. All experimental procedures in this study were performed according 135 to the Local Experimental Animal Care Committee and approved by the ethics of the 136 institutional committee of the Department of Poultry and Fish Diseases, Faculty of 137 Veterinary Medicine, Alexandria University, Egypt. All efforts were made to minimize 138Ten blood samples without anticoagulant were gathered from additional ten 141 one-day-old chicks by slaughtering for measuring maternally derived antibodies 142 specific for NDv. At weekly interval, blood samples were collected from the wing vein 143 of randomly selected twelve birds per group (four birds/ replicate) at 14 th , 21 th and 28 th 144 d, while at 35 th d, blood samples were collected from the surviving birds. Sera were 145 collected by centrifugation for 10 min. at 1500 ×g and were stored into eppindorff tubes 146 at -20°C until the use for serological tests. 147For haematological and phagocytic activity assays, blood samples were collected 148 at 28 th d with anticoagulant (sodium citrate 3.8%) from six birds in each group (NC, 149 VC, and VTC) (2 birds/replicate) and were sent to the laboratory at the same day. 150Immunological and haematological assays 151Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and classical ELISA tests were performed to measure 152 antibody titres (IgG) against ND, AI, IBD and IB. The HI test was performed in 153 U-based microtiter plates using 4 HA units of LaSota antigen (Intervet International (Synbiotics Co.). Haematological parameters were determined according to Campbell 157

The feed conversion ratio (FCR), 280 at the interval of 1 st to 28 th days of age (before challenge), was significantly worse 281 (p<0.05) in the vaccinated group (VC) (1.89 ± 0.04) when compared with that of 282 negative control birds (NC) (1.66 ± 0.04). Whereas, the use of EOs in VTC along with 283 vaccination resulted in a FCR of 1.77 ± 0.04, with no significant (p≥0.05) difference in 284 comparison with either NC or VC. 285 The feed conversion ratio during seven days PC was significantly (p<0.05) 286 higher in birds from PC (positive control) (2.83 ± 0.18) than that of all other 287 experimental groups. The best FCR (1.72 ± 0.09) was recorded by the negative control 288 birds (NC).
